elements.content: The synthesis of dipotassio-2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl)­silacyclopentadienediides K2[3] and germacyclopentadienediides K2[4] is reported. The prepared silole dianions, 3, are characterized by a significantly deshielded silicon nuclei with 29Si NMR signals at very unusual low field positions for silicon anions (δ29Si = 148–169). The results of DFT calculations revealed that this deshielding is a consequence of the silylene-like frontier orbitals of silole dianions 3 and efficient hyperconjugation between the trialkylsilyl-substituents and the cyclic delocalized π-system. Solid-state structure determinations of potassium salts of silole and germole dianions revealed a novel polymeric bis-η5,bis-η1-coordination mode between heterole and potassium ions.

Solid-state structure determinations of potassium salts of silole and germole dianions revealed a novel polymeric bis-η5,bis-η1-coordination mode between heterole and potassium ions.

elements.content: In the past, group 14 heterocyclopentadienediides (heterole dianions) have been of great interest because of the occurrence of electron delocalization involving the heteroatom. After the pioneering work by Joo and co-workers, the groups of West, Boudjouk, and Tilley provided convincing evidence for heteroaromaticity in several alkyl- and aryl-substituted silole and germole dianions (, A). The electronic situation in these heterole dianions is unique also due to the presence of a high lying lone pair at the heteroatom which is orthogonal to the cyclic π-system. The polarization of the empty π-orbitals of the cyclic conjugated systems (mainly the π4 orbital) toward the heteroatom generates a situation that is reminiscent to that of N-heterocyclic silylenes or germylenes (). Despite these intriguing properties of silole and germole dianions, little is known about their synthetic potential. This might be due to the reported low-yield synthesis of the alkali salts of the alkyl and aryl-substituted representatives of these dianions. In an elegant piece of work, the group of Saito extended the series of aromatic heterole dianions to tin and lead compounds (, A and B). The Saito group was also the first to apply trialkylsilyl substitution in the synthesis of stannole and plumbole dianions (, B). In particular, in the case of the stannole dianion, the trialkylsilyl substitution in the 2,5-position of the heterole ring had a remarkable effect on the electronic situation in the metalloaromatic system, which was expressed by marked low-field shifts of the 119Sn NMR resonances of stannole dianions B (E = Sn). We report here the synthesis and the structural characterization of potassium salts of silole and germole dianions 3 and 4 with trialkylsilyl groups in the 2,5-position of the five membered ring. This substitution pattern has a remarkable effect on their electronic situation and on their stability and allowed us to study the chemistry of these dianions in more detail. In addition, we would like to rectify a previous but erronous report on the NMR characterization of silole dianion 3a.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past, group 14 heterocyclopentadienediides (heterole dianions) have been of great interest because of the occurrence of electron delocalization involving the heteroatom. After the pioneering work by Joo and co-workers, the groups of West, Boudjouk, and Tilley provided convincing evidence for heteroaromaticity in several alkyl- and aryl-substituted silole and germole dianions (, A). The electronic situation in these heterole dianions is unique also due to the presence of a high lying lone pair at the heteroatom which is orthogonal to the cyclic π-system. The polarization of the empty π-orbitals of the cyclic conjugated systems (mainly the π4 orbital) toward the heteroatom generates a situation that is reminiscent to that of N-heterocyclic silylenes or germylenes (). Despite these intriguing properties of silole and germole dianions, little is known about their synthetic potential. This might be due to the reported low-yield synthesis of the alkali salts of the alkyl and aryl-substituted representatives of these dianions. In an elegant piece of work, the group of Saito extended the series of aromatic heterole dianions to tin and lead compounds (, A and B). The Saito group was also the first to apply trialkylsilyl substitution in the synthesis of stannole and plumbole dianions (, B). In particular, in the case of the stannole dianion, the trialkylsilyl substitution in the 2,5-position of the heterole ring had a remarkable effect on the electronic situation in the metalloaromatic system, which was expressed by marked low-field shifts of the 119Sn NMR resonances of stannole dianions B (E = Sn). We report here the synthesis and the structural characterization of potassium salts of silole and germole dianions 3 and 4 with trialkylsilyl groups in the 2,5-position of the five membered ring. This substitution pattern has a remarkable effect on their electronic situation and on their stability and allowed us to study the chemistry of these dianions in more detail. In addition, we would like to rectify a previous but erronous report on the NMR characterization of silole dianion 3a.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Characterization

Dipotassio-2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl)­siloles K2[3] were synthesized by adding THF to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorosiloles 1 and 10 equiv of potassium at room temperature (). The excess of potassium is essential for the success of the synthesis and can be reused after being washed with THF. This synthetic methodology can be extended to the formation of dipotassium 2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl)­germole dianions K2[4]. Noticeably, these reductions are scalable and we were able to produce the potassium salts of 2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl)-substituted silole and germole dianions in gram scale in contrast to the previous reported methods of alkali salts of aryl- and alkyl-substituted heterole dianions. All silole and germole dianions were fully characterized by NMR spectroscopy, and according to 1H NMR spectroscopy, the yields were quantitative with the exception of K2[3b]. In this case about 18% of unknown byproducts were detected. The obtained THF solutions can be used as obtained for subsequent reactions.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Dipotassio-2,5-bis(trialkylsilyl)siloles K2[3] were synthesized by adding THF to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorosiloles 1 and 10 equiv of potassium at room temperature (). The excess of potassium is essential for the success of the synthesis and can be reused after being washed with THF. This synthetic methodology can be extended to the formation of dipotassium 2,5-bis(trialkylsilyl)germole dianions K2[4]. Noticeably, these reductions are scalable and we were able to produce the potassium salts of 2,5-bis(trialkylsilyl)-substituted silole and germole dianions in gram scale in contrast to the previous reported methods of alkali salts of aryl- and alkyl-substituted heterole dianions. All silole and germole dianions were fully characterized by NMR spectroscopy, and according to 1H NMR spectroscopy, the yields were quantitative with the exception of K2[3b]. In this case about 18% of unknown byproducts were detected. The obtained THF solutions can be used as obtained for subsequent reactions.

elements.content:
Numbering indicates the here used assignment for the carbon atoms of the heterole ring.

The 13C NMR resonances of the C1/4 and C2/3 carbon atoms of the heterole rings of K2[3] and K2[4] are found in the region between δ13C = 130–156 and are assigned by 2D 1H/13C correlation NMR spectroscopy (see the Supporting Information). Their NMR chemical shifts are distinctly different from those of dichlorosiloles 1 and dichlorogermoles 2 () and indicate the switch from the neutral heterocyclopentadiene system to the dianionic aromatic compounds. Most significant are the 29Si NMR chemical shifts for the silicon atoms of silole rings of K2[3] measured in THF solution (δ29Si = 148.5 (K2[3a]); 161.4 (K2[3b])). These are markedly shifted to low field compared to those reported for alkyl- and aryl-substituted silole dianions (δ29Si = 30 (Li2[5]); 69 (Li2[6])) and N-heterocyclic silylene 7 (δ29Si = 78) (). For THF-solvate K2[3a]·2THF a slightly upfield-shifted 29Si NMR resonance was found in the solid state (δ29Si = 130.7) which is a consequence of the different coordination environment of the silicon atom in the solid state (see below) and in THF solution. Here we note that Kovács et al. reported previously the NMR characterization of K2[3a] and Na2[3a] with much smaller 29Si NMR chemical shifts (δ29Si = 49 (Na2[3a]); 45 (K2[3a])) close to those found for alkyl- and aryl-substituted silole dianions. The reported 29Si NMR chemical shifts by Kovács are however very close to those of bis-silolyldianion 8 in salt Na2[8] (δ29Si = 36.7) that was recently structurally characterized by the group of Han ().

DME = dimethoxyethane.

Yellow crystals of THF solvates of dipotassium silole dianion K2[3a] and dipotassium germole dianion K2[4a] suitable for X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were crystallized from THF/hexane (1:2) solution at −30 °C. The XRD analysis revealed very similar structure solutions for both compounds ( and ), and only the silole dianion crystal structure will be discussed here in detail. The silole rings form a one-dimensional polymeric zigzag chain along the a-axis of the crystal. The silole rings are connected by potassium ions that are coordinated in a η5-fashion to one silole ring and via the silicon atom of the neighboring ring in a η1-manner. Coordination with one THF molecule completes the coordination sphere of the potassium atoms. In the polymeric chain, each silole ring adopts a bis-η5, bis-η1 coordination mode. This arrangement, D, of alkali ions around the silole rings differs from the previously reported η5,η5- (A) or η5,η1- (B) arrangements found for isolated ion pairs of heterole dianions with alkali metal ions. It can be also distinguished from the polymeric η5,bis-η1 coordination (C) found for the dilithium salt of the 2,3,4,5-tetraethyl germole dianion (, and ).

elements.content: The silicon/potassium distances defining the η1-coordination (Si1–K1A/K2B, see ) are slightly longer than those for the η5-coordination (Si1–K1/K2, see ), and both are longer than those reported for [K­(18-crown-6)]2[9] (, Table S3). These large Si/K separations indicate the mostly ionic interaction between isolated potassium cations and silole anions. The silole ring in K2[3a] is planar (sum of the inner cyclic angles: 540.0°). The short Si–C1/4 bonds (186.0(12) and 186.1(12) pm) and the nearly equidistant innercyclic C–C bonds (142.3–143.8 pm) indicate the delocalization of the 6π-electrons of the silole dianion (). A very similar molecular structure and a comparable bonding situation were found in the solid-state structure of dipotassium germole dianion K2[4a] (). The only difference between these two heterole dianion structures are a trans bent arrangement of the two SiMe3 groups in K2[3a] that places the silicon atom of the trimethylsilyl group above/below the plane of the central SiC4 ring (distance d to the SiC4 plane: d(Si2/SiC4) = 36 pm; d(Si3/SiC4) = 27 pm, see ). In contrast, the two silicon atoms of the trimethylsilyl groups in K2[4a] are located in the plane spanned by germole ring (GeC4) ( and ). Despite these small distortions, the experimental structural parameters of dianions 3 and 4 clearly indicate their expected aromaticity, which is similar to that of aryl- and alky-substituted heterole dianions.

elements.content: We performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the M06-2X/def2-tzvp level of theory to understand the effect of trialkylsilylsubstitution on the stability and NMR properties of heterole dianions. The molecular structure of 3a calculated at this level is very close to that determined experimentally; the largest deviation in atomic distances is less than 1% (found for C2–C3). Gas phase calculations of the 29Si NMR chemical shift for the dianion 3a are not very accurate but predict in agreement with the experiment a strongly low-field-shifted resonance for the silole silicon atom (δ29Si­(calc) = 183, deviation from experiment Δδ29Si = +34, ). The 29Si NMR chemical shift obtained for the bis-η5-potassium complex of 3a in THF solution is closer to the experiment (δ29Si­(calc) = 159, deviation from experiment Δδ29Si = +10). This suggests that ion-pairing between the silole dianion and the potassium ions is important also in THF solution. Additional NMR chemical shift computations for 2,5-disilyl- and 2,5-dimethyl-substituted (10a and 10b) silole dianions and for nonsubstituted dianion 10c reveal the decisive influence of the 2,5-disilyl substitution on the NMR chemical shift of the inner cyclic silicon atom. According to basic theory of NMR chemical shielding, the 29Si NMR chemical shielding σ (and thereby the 29Si NMR chemical shift δ) is dominated by its paramagnetic (deshielding) term σ­(para). This contribution is determined by the energy difference between occupied and virtual orthogonal molecular orbitals with large coefficients at the silicon atom. The smaller the energy difference between the interacting molecular orbitals, the larger the σ­(para) and the more deshielded the silicon nuclei. The two molecular orbitals here of interest are the occupied in-plane lone pair at the silicon atom (LP­(Si)) and the lowest unoccupied π-orbital of the delocalized 6π-electron system (π(4)) which is largely polarized toward the silicon atom (see ; for a description of all π-orbital of the silole ring, see Figure S9). This electronic situation has parallels to that found in isoelectronic diaminosilylenes. Trialkylsilylsubstitution in the 2,5-positions lowers the energy of both orbitals, but due to efficient hyperconjugation, the unoccupied π(4) orbital is even more strongly influenced by the trialkylsilylsubstitution. As a result, the energy difference between both MOs decreases from parent silole dianion 10c to 2,5-dimethyl-substituted 10b to 2,5-disilyl substituted dianion 10a (see and ). The smallest energy difference is computed for dianion 3a. Along this sequence, the deshielding of the silicon nuclei increases significantly (from δ29Si = −3 (10c) to δ29Si = 183 (3a)). On the basis of our MO considerations, we can conclude that the remarkable deshielding of the silicon nuclei of 2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl)-substituted silole dianions is a result of efficient hyperconjugation between the trialkylsilyl substituents and the unoccupied π-orbitals of the silole ring. A similar additional deshielding of the tin nuclei was reported for bis­(dialkylsilyl)-substituted stannole dianions by Saito and co-workers. They attributed this low-field shift to a lower electron density at the tin atom as a consequence of the silyl substitution.

We performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the M06-2X/def2-tzvp level of theory to understand the effect of trialkylsilylsubstitution on the stability and NMR properties of heterole dianions. The molecular structure of 3a calculated at this level is very close to that determined experimentally; the largest deviation in atomic distances is less than 1% (found for C2-C3). The 29Si NMR chemical shift obtained for the bis-η5-potassium complex of 3a in THF solution is closer to the experiment (δ29Si(calc) = 159, deviation from experiment Δδ29Si = +10). This suggests that ion-pairing between the silole dianion and the potassium ions is important also in THF solution. This contribution is determined by the energy difference between occupied and virtual orthogonal molecular orbitals with large coefficients at the silicon atom. As a result, the energy difference between both MOs decreases from parent silole dianion 10c to 2,5-dimethyl-substituted 10b to 2,5-disilyl substituted dianion 10a (see  and ). A similar additional deshielding of the tin nuclei was reported for bis(dialkylsilyl)-substituted stannole dianions by Saito and co-workers. They attributed this low-field shift to a lower electron density at the tin atom as a consequence of the silyl substitution.

η5,η5-coordination of potassium ions to silole ring.

The significant changes in the electronic situation of silole and germole dianions which goes along with the 2,5-bis­(trialkylsilyl) substitution do have also a stabilizing influence. An estimate on the thermodynamic stabilization is provided by the isodesmic reaction shown in . The calculated reaction energies show that the σ–π* hyperconjugative interaction between 2,5-bis­(trialkysilyl)­substitutents and heterole rings provides a thermodynamical stabilization of silole dianion 10a by −211 kJ mol–1 and of germole dianion 11a by −171 kJ mol–1 compared to the respective nonsubstituted heterole dianion. The results of the DFT calculations gave also indications for the aromaticity of silole and germole dianions 10 and 11. Nucleus-independent chemical shift (NICS) calculations gave values for the two heterole dianions that are very similar to those predicted for typical aromatic carbocycles such as cyclopentadienide (Cp–) and benzene. For example, NICS values computed 10 pm above the ring center are only slightly smaller than those obtained for benzene or Cp– (NICS = −8.1 (10a), −8.6 (11a), −10.5 (Cp–) and −10.2 (benzene), see the Supporting Information for more details). According to the NICS aromaticity criteria, the aromaticity of silole and germole dianions is only slightly affected by the substituents at the 2- and 5-positions. For example, very similar NICS values are computed for 10a–c (NICS = −8.1 (10a), −7.2 (10b), −9.7 (10c), see the Supporting Information for more details).

Conclusion

In conclusion, we have reported an efficient approach to synthesize dipotassium salts of 2,5-bis­(dialkylsilyl)­substituted silole- [3] and germole dianions [4] under mild conditions in high yields. The solid-state structures of K2[3a] and K2[4a] revealed a polymeric η5,η5,η1,η1-coordination pattern between potassium ions and the anionic heterole. In solution, silole dianions 3a,b are characterized by unusal deshielded silicon nuclei (δ29Si = 148.5 (3a) and 161.4 (3b)) at approximatively 100 ppm lower field than related silole dianions such as dianions 5 and 6. 29Si solid state MAS NMR measurements for K2[3a]·2THF (δ29Si = 130.7), indicate the presence of the same dianionic species in solution and in the solid state. The results of DFT calculations suggested that this unusual deshielding of the silicon nucleus in dianions 3 is a consequence of efficient hyperconjugation between the trialkylsilyl substituents and the π-electron system of the silole ring. We point out that a previous report by the group of Kovacs on the synthesis and NMR characterization of the sodium and potassium salt of silole dianion 3a reports a quite different 29Si NMR chemical shift for this species (δ29Si = 45 and 49 depending on the Gegenion). This chemical shift value is however close to that reported by Han for the sodium bis-(silolyl-anion) 8 (δ29Si = 37). On the basis of the very similar 29Si NMR chemical shifts, we suggest that the species investigated by Kovacs et al. by 29Si NMR spectroscopy is actually bis-(silolyl anion) 8 and not silole dianion 3a. In our preparation of heterole dianions 3 and 4, we found it essential to use a large excess of potassium to achieve a complete conversion of starting heterole dichlorides 1 and 2. We suggest that the use of only slight excess of alkali metal (5 equiv) for the reduction of the dihalide as reported by Kovacs at al. is not sufficient to prevent the formation of the Si–Si bonded dimer and does not allow the reductive cleavage of the Si–Si bond. This idea is supported by the experimental details reported by the Han group which uses 4.8 equiv of sodium metal for the synthesis of Na2[8].

elements.content: All the reactions were performed under dry argon atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques or in a nitrogen-filled glovebox. The solvents THF, diethyl ether (Et2O), benzene, and n-pentane were dried over sodium/potassium alloy and distilled under nitrogen prior to use. Deuterated benzene-d6 was dried over sodium/potassium alloy, distilled and stored over molecular sieve (4 Å). Details of experimental procedures, NMR spectra and X-ray structure determinations are given in the Supporting Information. No satisfying combustion analysis was obtained for the bulk material of compounds K2[3] and K2[4], due to the sensitivity of the samples against moisture and air and due to contamination of the samples with variable amounts of THF and KCl. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance DRX 500 and Bruker Avance III 500 spectrometers. Spectra were calibrated as follows: 1H NMR against the residual proton signal of the solvent as internal reference (benzene-d 6: δ 1H­(C6D5H) = 7.20; D2O: δ 1H­(HDO) = 4.79) and 13C­{1H} NMR by using the central line of the solvent signal (benzene-d 6: δ 13C (C6D6) = 128.0). The 29Si­{1H} NMR inverse gated spectra were recorded with a relaxation delay D1 = 10 s. The 29Si­{1H} INEPT spectra were recorded with the combination of D3 = 0.0068 s and D4 = 0.0313 s. All the NMR data of silole dianions K2[3] and germole dianions K2[4] were recorded in THF in the presence of a sealed capillary containing D2O.

Experimental Section

All the reactions were performed under dry argon atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques or in a nitrogen-filled glovebox. The solvents THF, diethyl ether (Et2O), benzene, and n-pentane were dried over sodium/potassium alloy and distilled under nitrogen prior to use. Deuterated benzene-d6 was dried over sodium/potassium alloy, distilled and stored over molecular sieve (4 Å). Details of experimental procedures, NMR spectra and X-ray structure determinations are given in the Supporting Information. No satisfying combustion analysis was obtained for the bulk material of compounds K2[3] and K2[4], due to the sensitivity of the samples against moisture and air and due to contamination of the samples with variable amounts of THF and KCl. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance DRX 500 and Bruker Avance III 500 spectrometers. Spectra were calibrated as follows: 1H NMR against the residual proton signal of the solvent as internal reference (benzene-d 6: δ 1H(C6D5H) = 7.20; D2O: δ 1H(HDO) = 4.79) and 13C{1H} NMR by using the central line of the solvent signal (benzene-d 6: δ 13C (C6D6) = 128.0). The 29Si{1H} NMR inverse gated spectra were recorded with a relaxation delay D1 = 10 s. The 29Si{1H} INEPT spectra were recorded with the combination of D3 = 0.0068 s and D4 = 0.0313 s. All the NMR data of silole dianions K2[3] and germole dianions K2[4] were recorded in THF in the presence of a sealed capillary containing D2O.

elements.content: At room temperature, THF (25 mL) was added to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorosilole 1a (400 mg, 0.894 mmol) and 10 equiv of K (349.4 mg, 8.94 mmol) and the reaction mixture kept stirring overnight. The resulting deep red-brown solution was filtered by using a PTFE syringe filter to remove the KCl. The filtrate was used for NMR spectroscopy without any further purification. On the basis of the analysis of the NMR spectra, the yield of compound K2[3a] is almost quantitative. For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. Suitable yellow crystals of K2[3a] were obtained by recrystallization from THF/hexane (1:2) at −30 °C. 1H NMR (499.87 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 7.22–7.25 (m, 8H, Ph), 7.07–7.09 (m, 2H, Ph), 0.39 (s, 18H, Si­(CH3)3). 13C­{1H} NMR (125.71 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 149.9 (C ipso –Ph), 145.8 (2 × CSi), 140.5 (2 × CPh), 130.4 (Ph), 126.1 (Ph), 121.1 (Ph), 5.6 (Si­(CH3)3). 29Si­{1H} NMR (99.31 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 148.5 (SiC4), −15.8 (Si­(CH3)3). CP MAS 29Si NMR: 130.7 (SiC4), −14.8 (Si­(CH3)3).

For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. 1H NMR spectroscopy indicated almost quantitative formation of compound K2[4b]. 1H NMR (499.9 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 0.50 (s, 12H, Si­(CH 3)2), 1.29­(s, 18H, SiC­(CH 3)3), 2.56 (s, 6H, CH 3). 13C­{1H} NMR (125.7 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 0.0 (Si­(CH 3)2), 17.5 (SiC­(CH3)3), 21.6 (CH3), 28.3 (SiC­(CH3)3), 129.6 (2 × CCH3), 150.8 (2 × CSi). 29Si­{1H} NMR (99.3 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = −5.9 (Si­(CH3)3).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Silole Dianion K2[3a]

At room temperature, THF (25 mL) was added to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorosilole 1a (400 mg, 0.894 mmol) and 10 equiv of K (349.4 mg, 8.94 mmol) and the reaction mixture kept stirring overnight. The resulting deep red-brown solution was filtered by using a PTFE syringe filter to remove the KCl. The filtrate was used for NMR spectroscopy without any further purification. On the basis of the analysis of the NMR spectra, the yield of compound K2[3a] is almost quantitative. For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. Suitable yellow crystals of K2[3a] were obtained by recrystallization from THF/hexane (1:2) at -30 °C. 1H NMR (499.87 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 7.22-7.25 (m, 8H, Ph), 7.07-7.09 (m, 2H, Ph), 0.39 (s, 18H, Si(CH3)3). 13C{1H} NMR (125.71 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 149.9 (C  ipso -Ph), 145.8 (2 × CSi), 140.5 (2 × CPh), 130.4 (Ph), 126.1 (Ph), 121.1 (Ph), 5.6 (Si(CH3)3). 29Si{1H} NMR (99.31 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 148.5 (SiC4), -15.8 (Si(CH3)3). CP MAS 29Si NMR: 130.7 (SiC4), -14.8 (Si(CH3)3).

Synthesis of Silole Dianion K2[3b]

At room temperature, THF (5 mL) was added to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorosilole 1b (237.7 mg, 0.447 mmol) and 10 equiv of K (174.7 mg, 4.47 mmol), and the reaction mixture kept stirring overnight. The resulting deep red-brown solution was filtered by using a PTFE syringe filter to remove the KCl. The filtrate was used for NMR spectroscopy without any further purification. On the basis of the analysis of the NMR spectra, compound K2[3b] is contaminated with unknown byproducts (less than 18% from 1H NMR spectroscopy). For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. 1H NMR (499.87 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 7.20-6.85 (m, 10H, Ph), 1.24-1.27 (t, 3 J H,H = 7.9 Hz, 18H, Si(CH2CH 3)3), 0.90-0.95 (q, 3 J H,H = 7.9 Hz, 12H, Si(CH 2CH3)3). 13C{1H} NMR (125.71 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 150.1 (C  ipso -Ph), 140.3 (2 × CPh), 140.1 (2 × CSi), 130.3 (Ph), 126.0 (Ph), 121.1 (Ph), 9.0 (Si(CH2 CH3)3), 8.6 (Si(CH2CH3)3). 29Si{1H} NMR (99.31 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 161.4 (SiC4), -6.3 (Si(CH2CH3)3).

Synthesis of Germole Dianion K2[4a]

At room temperature, THF (25 mL) was added to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorogermole 2a (1.500 g, 4.08 mmol) and 10 equiv of K (1.590 g, 40.80 mmol), and the reaction mixture kept stirring overnight. The red-brown solution was filtered by using a PTFE syringe filter to remove the KCl. The filtrate was used for NMR spectroscopy without any purification. 1H NMR spectroscopy indicated almost quantitative formation of compound K2[4a]. For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. Recrystallization of the residue from THF/hexane (1:2) at -30 °C afforded K2[4a] as air- and moisture-sensitive yellow crystals. 1H NMR (499.9 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 0.35 (s, 18H, Si(CH 3)3), 2.47 (s, 6H, CH 3). 13C{1H} NMR (125.7 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 4.9 (Si(CH3)3), 20.9 (CH3), 130.8 (2 × CCH3), 156.2 (2 × CSi). 29Si{1H} NMR (99.3 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = -15.9 (Si(CH3)3).

Synthesis of Germole Dianion K2[4b]

At room temperature, THF (5 mL) was added to a mixture of 1 equiv of dichlorogermole 2b (246 mg, 0.543 mmol) and 10 equiv of K (212 mg, 5.43 mmol), and the reaction mixture kept stirring overnight. The red-brown solution was filtered by using a PTFE syringe filter to remove the KCl. The filtrate was used for NMR spectroscopy without any purification. For further reactions, it is recommended to use this solution. 1H NMR spectroscopy indicated almost quantitative formation of compound K2[4b]. 1H NMR (499.9 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 0.50 (s, 12H, Si(CH 3)2), 1.29(s, 18H, SiC(CH 3)3), 2.56 (s, 6H, CH 3). 13C{1H} NMR (125.7 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = 0.0 (Si(CH 3)2), 17.5 (SiC(CH3)3), 21.6 (CH3), 28.3 (SiC(CH3)3), 129.6 (2 × CCH3), 150.8 (2 × CSi). 29Si{1H} NMR (99.3 MHz, 305.0 K, THF): δ = -5.9 (Si(CH3)3).
